title: How to tell the time in Spanish - Quora

response.answer_text: to tell time in spanish …the form is form of 'SER’+feminine form of the(la)+number for AM you say “de la mañana” for PM you say “de la tarde(for afternoon)..and “de la noche”(for night) ex: 6:00am —son las seis de la mañana ex: 8:00pm—son las ocho de la noche however for 1 o’clock you use “es” singular form of “ser” 1:00—es la una for after hour we use particle “y” meaning and for before hour we use particle “menos” meaning minus/less quarter in spanish is called “cuarto” following examples will clear your all problems 2:15 am—son las dos y cuarto de la mañana 3:45—son las cuatro(four) menos cuarto 3:20—son las tres y viente we use ”media” as 30 or for middle of your 1:30—A una y media you can use de la mañana/tarde/noche as required

Somewhat complex.General structure: “Son las <hour> y <minute>”. If it’s 1, the singular is used: “Es la una”. We use the 12-hour clock. You won’t hear anyone saying “son las diecisiete y media”, it’s just awkward. The <minute> part goes like this: 00 (o’clock) -> “en punto”, although it’s usually omitted unless it’s relevant. 14:00 goes “son las dos en punto”.Between 1 and 29 -> “y <number>”. We usually round to the nearest multiple of five. It’s normal to hear “seis y diez” when it’s 18:08. When it’s rounded down it goes like this: “son las ocho y cuarto pasadas” for 20:17.15 -> “y cuarto”30 -> “y media”Between 31 and 59 -> “<hour+1> menos <number>”. 8:55 -> “nueve menos cinco”. Very much alike “five minutes to nine”.45 -> “menos cuarto”.The am/pm equivalents are complex and many times optional. If it can be inferred whether the speaker means am or pm it’s omitted (and if the listener can’t, well, he just asks). Noon (12:00) = “Es mediodía”.Midnight (00:00) = “Es medianoche”. Just that.From 1 am to 12 am -> “de la mañana”.1 am to 6 am -> “de la madrugada”. Yes there’s quite a bit of overlap.9 pm to 12 pm -> “de la noche”.1 pm to 8 pm -> “de la tarde”.
